message: Outcasts United by Warren St. John. Our community reads book for 2011. The real story of a small town near Atlanta, GA that has seen an influx of refugees from all over the world. How one woman, Luma Mufleh, herself an immigrant from Jordan, brings together young boys by creating and coaching soccer teams for them.
It's a good book. Not great, but good.
as writing books go, it's pretty good
somewhat embarassingly, before that i was re-reading the the harry potter series, since the final movie was coming out
i was hoping JKR would release her background notes, since apparently she developed huge amounts of back-story that never made it into the books
There's a new book for writers out. It was featured on PBS The News Hour. Let me look it up...
interesting.... i've been very anti-writing books the last few years
i only read the writer's mentor because my step-mom gave it to me for christmas
I bet they will! Haha should be a new group: Convore Conventions. Should I?
Not so embarassing! I just re-read the last one, also to be prepped for the final movie. It struck me again what a great story it is.
yeah, it's truly an epic... i kind of want more, though i don't want the legacy to be tarnished
"Unless It Moves The Human Heart: The Craft and Art of Writing," http://www.pbs.org/newshour/art/blog/2011/01/mondays-newshour-roger-rosenblatt-has-advice-for-writers.html
I'm waiting for you hahaha. Are you waiting for me
yeah
Ok, I'll go!
this is an interesting question, how will convore culture develop
like, people will invent conventions/protocols for topic branching
Right now I'm reading the Writer's Mentor, which is about the writing life
It really sounded wonderful, based on many classes that Roger Rosenblatt has taught.
Want to start a new topic?
it was buried deep on my amazon wishlist, but she somehow dug it out
sure
oh, yeah, totally
that would be a great group
This weekend, I finished both Super Sad True Love Story and Nox. That was a wild reading ride.
And...?
What did you think? I'm done with Outcasts United, so now I can finally read Good Squad!
Ender's Shadow, by Orson Scott Card, now reading the Singularity is Near, by Ray Kurzweil.
I mean, GooN Squad!
Oooh, just checked out the book online. And a movie too.
Ender's Shadow - Great book. Haven't heard about Singularity. New book or old?
Just so you know, that movie is likely to be more of a documentary format. So far it's a great book though, incredible ideas that I'd never considered.
That made me think of the Red Mars trilogy: created new topic Sci-Fi.
Reading Age of Wonder.
World War Z - and I loved it; enough to re-read it again!
Sounds heavy - is it a good read?
"Virtual Light" by Gibson. Enjoyed it overall. Looking forward to picking up the last book in the trilogy. (I read "Idoru" first.)
Pragmatic Thinking and Learning -- Lots of fun to read, tons of insights into the brain and psychology with fun ties back to programming.
I really liked his Pattern Recognition.
Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughterhouse-Five
Just finished Charles Stross's The Fuller Memorandum, the third book in The Laundry series. Best of the bunch thus far...could not put it down.
I'm now rereading Dante's Inferno, since I'm engaged in a rewrite of my novel "The Deep & Savage Way", which heavily parallels it
the edition i like is the oxford edition, translated and with commentary by John D. Sinclair
Wow, congratulations on your endeavor. I don't think I know anyone who's read Dante's Inferno. Is there a particular edition you recommend? Do you have a publisher for your book?
@Anneflo i originally read it when I was a lit student at UCSC
Good to know, thanks.
I love the name of your book BTW!\
@Anneflo thank! once it's available on amazon i'll let you know
I'm very much looking forward to it.
i have another book that will be available sooner, Collected Works
I am finishing False Gods, book 2 of the Horus Heresy from Games Workshop's Black Library.  Really enjoyed book 1 and likewise this one.  It was my introduction into the Warhammer 40k universe.

Currently I'm reading academic books. At the moment it's Analytic Philosophy: The History of an Illusion, which is good. I found it in my library's recent acquisitions along with an anthology on journalism in Web 2.0. I'll read that next.
@amycrea Is SSTLS worth reading?

I just finished reading Alone by Lisa Gardener. If you like mysteries, she's worth checking out. I've moved on to E.E. Knight's Vampire earth series. So far, the first book (Way Of the Wolf) is pretty good.
Apart from software engineering books. Last one was This Perfect Day by Ira Levin. Amazing book and short enough to encourage you to read it in one or two gos.
Just finished reading Darkfever by Karen Marie Moning. I liked it, but not enough to continue the series. At least, not right now anyway. Perhaps I'll come back to it later.
